A note on Burgess bound

Abstract.

Let f𝑓f be a S​L​(2,ℤ)𝑆𝐿2ℤSL(2,\mathbb{Z}) Hecke cusp form, and let χ𝜒\chi be a primitive Dirichlet character modulo M𝑀M, which we assume to be prime. We prove the Burgess type bound for the twisted L𝐿L-function:

L​(12,f⊗χ)≪f,εM1/2−1/8+ε.subscriptmuch-less-than𝑓𝜀𝐿12tensor-product𝑓𝜒superscript𝑀1218𝜀\displaystyle L\left(\tfrac{1}{2},f\otimes\chi\right)\ll_{f,\varepsilon}M^{1/2-1/8+\varepsilon}.

The method also yields the original bound of Burgess for Dirichlet L𝐿L-functions:

L​(12,χ)≪εM1/4−1/16+ε.subscriptmuch-less-than𝜀𝐿12𝜒superscript𝑀14116𝜀\displaystyle L\left(\tfrac{1}{2},\chi\right)\ll_{\varepsilon}M^{1/4-1/16+\varepsilon}.
Key words and phrases:
subconvexity, Hecke cusp forms, twisted L𝐿L-functions
2010 Mathematics Subject Classification:
11F66
The author is supported by SwarnaJayanti Fellowship, 2011-12, DST, Government of India.

1. Introduction

In the series of papers [15], [16], [17], [18] and [20] a new approach to prove subconvexity has been proposed. This method has turned out to be quite effective in the case of degree three L𝐿L-functions. Indeed if π𝜋\pi is a S​L​(3,ℤ)𝑆𝐿3ℤSL(3,\mathbb{Z}) Hecke-Maass cusp form then the t𝑡t aspect subconvex bound

L​(12+i​t,π)≪(2+|t|)3/4−1/16+ε,much-less-than𝐿12𝑖𝑡𝜋superscript2𝑡34116𝜀\displaystyle L(\tfrac{1}{2}+it,\pi)\ll(2+|t|)^{3/4-1/16+\varepsilon},

was established in [17], and if χ𝜒\chi is a primitive Dirichlet character modulo a prime M𝑀M, then the twist aspect subconvex bound

L​(12,π⊗χ)≪M3/4−1/308+ε,much-less-than𝐿12tensor-product𝜋𝜒superscript𝑀341308𝜀\displaystyle L(\tfrac{1}{2},\pi\otimes\chi)\ll M^{3/4-1/308+\varepsilon},

was established in [18] and [20]. In the special case, where π𝜋\pi is a symmetric square lift of a S​L​(2,ℤ)𝑆𝐿2ℤSL(2,\mathbb{Z}) form, then the former bound was previously obtained by Li [13], building on the work of Conrey and Iwaniec [8]. Again for π𝜋\pi a symmetric square lift and χ𝜒\chi a quadratic character, a subconvex bound (with a much stronger exponent) in the latter case was previously obtained by Blomer [2]. The works of Li and Blomer fail to extend to the general case as the non-negativity of the central value of L𝐿L-functions, which plays a vital role in their approach, ceases to hold in general. In contrast the method of [17], [18], [20] does not rely on this delicate feature.

Recently, Aggarwal [1] showed that the computations in [17] when adapted in the G​L​(2)𝐺𝐿2GL(2) scenario yields the Burgess exponent in the t𝑡t aspect. Taking a step further, refining certain estimates for exponential integral in [17], Singh [22] established the Weyl exponent in the t𝑡t aspect for G​L​(2)𝐺𝐿2GL(2) L𝐿L-functions

L​(12+i​t,g)≪(2+|t|)1/3+ε.much-less-than𝐿12𝑖𝑡𝑔superscript2𝑡13𝜀\displaystyle L(\tfrac{1}{2}+it,g)\ll(2+|t|)^{1/3+\varepsilon}.

Here g𝑔g is a Hecke modular or a Maass cuspform. This is of course the celebrated result of Good [10], which still remains the record though the corresponding exponent for the Riemann zeta function ζ​(s)𝜁𝑠\zeta(s) has gone through several improvements. It is now natural to ask what would one get if one had adopted the method of [18], [20], in the G​L​(2)𝐺𝐿2GL(2) context. The aim of the present note is to give a brief analysis of this possibility. We show that the method yields the Burgess type bound.

Theorem 1.

Suppose g𝑔g is a S​L​(2,ℤ)𝑆𝐿2ℤSL(2,\mathbb{Z}) Hecke cusp form, and χ𝜒\chi is a primitive Dirichlet character modulo M𝑀M (which we assume to be prime). Then we have

L​(12,g⊗χ)≪M1/2−1/8+ε.much-less-than𝐿12tensor-product𝑔𝜒superscript𝑀1218𝜀\displaystyle L\left(\tfrac{1}{2},g\otimes\chi\right)\ll M^{1/2-1/8+\varepsilon}. (1)

The exponent 1/2+ε12𝜀1/2+\varepsilon corresponds to the convexity bound, which follows easily from the functional equation and basic complex analysis. The Riemann Hypothesis for L​(s,g⊗χ)𝐿𝑠tensor-product𝑔𝜒L(s,g\otimes\chi) implies the much stronger bound - the Lindelof Hypothesis -

L​(12,g⊗χ)≪Mε.much-less-than𝐿12tensor-product𝑔𝜒superscript𝑀𝜀\displaystyle L\left(\tfrac{1}{2},g\otimes\chi\right)\ll M^{\varepsilon}.

Our result (1) is of course not new. Blomer and Harcos [3] established the Burgess exponent using Bykovskii’s method. The weaker exponent 1/2−(1−2​θ)/81212𝜃81/2-(1-2\theta)/8, where θ𝜃\theta is the exponent towards the Ramanujan conjecture, was previously established by Blomer, Harcos and Michel [4]. The latter exponent becomes Burgess under the Ramanujan conjecture θ=0𝜃0\theta=0. The first non-trivial bound of this sort, albeit with a weaker exponent, was obtained by Duke, Friedlander and Iwaniec [9]. The Burgess bound, even in the original set up of Burgess [7] for Dirichlet L𝐿L-functions, still remains the record (though it has been improved in certain special cases - see e.g. [5], [8], [14], [21]). Any improvement over this will be a major breakthrough in the field.

Our analysis should work even when M𝑀M is not a prime, but for simplicity we only provide a sketch for M𝑀M prime. From the technical point of view this paper puts the G​L​(2)𝐺𝐿2GL(2) delta method of [19], [20] in a better perspective. We closely follow [20]. In particular, we use the G​L​(2)𝐺𝐿2GL(2) analogue of the ‘congruence-equation trick’ (see [6], [16], [19]) and the trick of splitting a dual variable of summation to optimize the saving after an application of Cauchy inequality. The G​L​(2)𝐺𝐿2GL(2) set up simplifies certain technicalities, e.g. there is no need to sum over the modulus after dualization. However the extra sum over the level of forms (i.e. p𝑝p below) becomes redundant. This phenomenon is typical in G​L​(2)𝐺𝐿2GL(2) set up, and that this sum provides the extra harmonics needed in the degree three case indicates that one should try to understand this in the amplification technique set up so as to extend that technique beyond G​L​(2)𝐺𝐿2GL(2). We also observe that the cuspidality of g𝑔g is not required in the proof, and the proof holds even when the Fourier coefficient λg​(n)subscript𝜆𝑔𝑛\lambda_{g}(n) is replaced by the divisor function d​(n)𝑑𝑛d(n). In this way we can derive the classic result of Burgess.

Theorem 2.

Suppose χ𝜒\chi is a primitive Dirichlet character modulo M𝑀M (which we assume to be prime). Then we have

L​(12,χ)≪M1/4−1/16+ε.much-less-than𝐿12𝜒superscript𝑀14116𝜀\displaystyle L\left(\tfrac{1}{2},\chi\right)\ll M^{1/4-1/16+\varepsilon}. (2)

Acknowledgement.

The author wishes to thank Roman Holowinsky for several insightful comments. He thanks the referee for helpful suggestions.

2. Idea of the proof

To get a subconvex bound for L​(1/2,χ)2𝐿superscript12𝜒2L(1/2,\chi)^{2} one is led via the approximate functional equation to consider sums of the form

S​(N)=∑n∼Nd​(n)​χ​(n)𝑆𝑁subscriptsimilar-to𝑛𝑁𝑑𝑛𝜒𝑛\displaystyle S(N)=\sum_{n\sim N}d(n)\chi(n)

where d​(n)𝑑𝑛d(n) is the divisor function and N≪M1+εmuch-less-than𝑁superscript𝑀1𝜀N\ll M^{1+\varepsilon}. We want to establish a bound of the form |S​(N)|/N≪M1/2−θmuch-less-than𝑆𝑁𝑁superscript𝑀12𝜃|S(N)|/\sqrt{N}\ll M^{1/2-\theta} for some θ>0𝜃0\theta>0. Roughly speaking, our first step is to rewrite the sum S​(N)𝑆𝑁S(N) as

L−1​∑ℓ∈ℒ∑n∼N​L∑r∼Nd​(n)​χ​(r)​δ​(n,r​ℓ)superscript𝐿1subscriptℓℒsubscriptsimilar-to𝑛𝑁𝐿subscriptsimilar-to𝑟𝑁𝑑𝑛𝜒𝑟𝛿𝑛𝑟ℓ\displaystyle L^{-1}\sum_{\ell\in\mathscr{L}}\>\sum_{n\sim NL}\>\sum_{r\sim N}d(n)\chi(r)\delta(n,r\ell)

where ℒℒ\mathscr{L} is a set of L𝐿L primes of size L1+εsuperscript𝐿1𝜀L^{1+\varepsilon}, and δ(.,.)\delta(.,.) is the Kronecker delta symbol. Our job is to save N3/2​L​Mθ−1/2superscript𝑁32𝐿superscript𝑀𝜃12N^{3/2}LM^{\theta-1/2} for some θ>0𝜃0\theta>0. To this end we use the harmonics from the space Sk​(p​M,ψ)subscript𝑆𝑘𝑝𝑀𝜓S_{k}(pM,\psi) of cusp forms of weight k𝑘k, level p​M𝑝𝑀pM and nebentypus ψ𝜓\psi, to detect the equation n=r​ℓ𝑛𝑟ℓn=r\ell (see (3)). Here p𝑝p is a fixed prime and ψ𝜓\psi is a non-primitive odd character modulo p​M𝑝𝑀pM of conductor p𝑝p. This yields two terms - the off-diagonal contribution involving Kloosterman sums and the dual contribution involving the Fourier coefficients of cusp forms. The off-diagonal contribution is negligibly small if we pick p≫N​L​Mε/Mmuch-greater-than𝑝𝑁𝐿superscript𝑀𝜀𝑀p\gg NLM^{\varepsilon}/M, as it involves the J𝐽J-Bessel function

Jk−1​(4​π​n​r​ℓc​p​M),subscript𝐽𝑘14𝜋𝑛𝑟ℓ𝑐𝑝𝑀\displaystyle J_{k-1}\left(\frac{4\pi\sqrt{nr\ell}}{cpM}\right),

with c𝑐c a positive integer. Note that we are taking k𝑘k to be large, like 1/ε1𝜀1/\varepsilon, and one has the bound Jk−1​(x)≪xk−1much-less-thansubscript𝐽𝑘1𝑥superscript𝑥𝑘1J_{k-1}(x)\ll x^{k-1}.

The dual term is given by

∑ψmodp∑ℓ∈ℒ∑f∈Hk​(p​M,ψ)ωf−1​∑n∼N​Ld​(n)​λf​(n)​∑r∼Nλf​(r​ℓ)¯​χ​(r),subscriptmodulo𝜓𝑝subscriptℓℒsubscript𝑓subscript𝐻𝑘𝑝𝑀𝜓superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑓1subscriptsimilar-to𝑛𝑁𝐿𝑑𝑛subscript𝜆𝑓𝑛subscriptsimilar-to𝑟𝑁¯subscript𝜆𝑓𝑟ℓ𝜒𝑟\displaystyle\sum_{\psi\bmod{p}}\>\sum_{\ell\in\mathscr{L}}\>\sum_{f\in H_{k}(pM,\psi)}\>\omega_{f}^{-1}\sum_{n\sim NL}\>d(n)\lambda_{f}(n)\sum_{r\sim N}\overline{\lambda_{f}(r\ell)}\chi(r),

where our job is to save N3/2​L​Mθ−1/2superscript𝑁32𝐿superscript𝑀𝜃12N^{3/2}LM^{\theta-1/2} for some θ>0𝜃0\theta>0. Next we apply summation formulas on the sum over n𝑛n and r𝑟r. These can be derived, for example, from the functional equations of L​(s,f)2𝐿superscript𝑠𝑓2L(s,f)^{2} and L​(s,f⊗χ)𝐿𝑠tensor-product𝑓𝜒L(s,f\otimes\chi) respectively. With this the above sum reduces to

∑ψmodp∑ℓ∈ℒ∑f∈Hk​(p​M,ψ)ωf−1​gψ​∑n∼p2​M2/N​Ld​(n)​λf​(n​p​ℓ)¯​∑r∼p​M2/Nλf​(r)​χ​(r)¯,subscriptmodulo𝜓𝑝subscriptℓℒsubscript𝑓subscript𝐻𝑘𝑝𝑀𝜓superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑓1subscript𝑔𝜓subscriptsimilar-to𝑛superscript𝑝2superscript𝑀2𝑁𝐿𝑑𝑛¯subscript𝜆𝑓𝑛𝑝ℓsubscriptsimilar-to𝑟𝑝superscript𝑀2𝑁subscript𝜆𝑓𝑟¯𝜒𝑟\displaystyle\sum_{\psi\bmod{p}}\>\sum_{\ell\in\mathscr{L}}\>\sum_{f\in H_{k}(pM,\psi)}\>\omega_{f}^{-1}\>g_{\psi}\sum_{n\sim p^{2}M^{2}/NL}\>d(n)\overline{\lambda_{f}(np\ell)}\sum_{r\sim pM^{2}/N}\lambda_{f}(r)\overline{\chi(r)},

and we make a saving of size (N​L/p​M)​(N/p​M)𝑁𝐿𝑝𝑀𝑁𝑝𝑀(NL/pM)(N/\sqrt{p}M). Here gψsubscript𝑔𝜓g_{\psi} stands for the Gauss sum associated with ψ𝜓\psi. It now remains to save p3/2​M3/2+θ/Nsuperscript𝑝32superscript𝑀32𝜃𝑁p^{3/2}M^{3/2+\theta}/\sqrt{N}. We now apply the Petersson formula. The diagonal is easily seen to be small due to size of the variables. The off-diagonal is roughly of the form

∑ψmodpgψ​∑ℓ∈ℒ∑n∼p2​M2/N​Ld​(n)​∑r∼p​M2/Nχ​(r)¯​∑c≪p​M/NSψ​(n​p​ℓ,r;c​p​M).subscriptmodulo𝜓𝑝subscript𝑔𝜓subscriptℓℒsubscriptsimilar-to𝑛superscript𝑝2superscript𝑀2𝑁𝐿𝑑𝑛subscriptsimilar-to𝑟𝑝superscript𝑀2𝑁¯𝜒𝑟subscriptmuch-less-than𝑐𝑝𝑀𝑁subscript𝑆𝜓𝑛𝑝ℓ𝑟𝑐𝑝𝑀\displaystyle\sum_{\psi\bmod{p}}\>g_{\psi}\sum_{\ell\in\mathscr{L}}\>\sum_{n\sim p^{2}M^{2}/NL}\>d(n)\sum_{r\sim pM^{2}/N}\overline{\chi(r)}\sum_{c\ll pM/N}S_{\psi}(np\ell,r;cpM).

In the off-diagonal the Petersson formula saves p​M/size of​c=N𝑝𝑀size of𝑐𝑁\sqrt{pM}/\sqrt{\text{size of}\>c}=\sqrt{N}, and then applying the Poisson summation formula on the sum over r𝑟r we save (p​M2/N)/p2​M2/N=M/N𝑝superscript𝑀2𝑁superscript𝑝2superscript𝑀2𝑁𝑀𝑁(pM^{2}/N)/\sqrt{p^{2}M^{2}/N}=M/\sqrt{N}. The sum over ψ𝜓\psi saves p𝑝\sqrt{p} more, and with this we arrive at the expression

∑ℓ∈ℒ∑n∼p2​M2/N​Ld​(n)​∑r∼p∑c≪p​M/Ne​(c¯​n​ℓr​M)​χ​(c)¯​ℭsubscriptℓℒsubscriptsimilar-to𝑛superscript𝑝2superscript𝑀2𝑁𝐿𝑑𝑛subscriptsimilar-to𝑟𝑝subscriptmuch-less-than𝑐𝑝𝑀𝑁𝑒¯𝑐𝑛ℓ𝑟𝑀¯𝜒𝑐ℭ\displaystyle\sum_{\ell\in\mathscr{L}}\>\sum_{n\sim p^{2}M^{2}/NL}\>d(n)\sum_{r\sim p}\>\sum_{c\ll pM/N}\>e\left(\frac{\overline{c}n\ell}{rM}\right)\overline{\chi(c)}\>\mathfrak{C}

where

ℭ=∑amodMχ​(a¯+r)​e​(a​c¯​n​ℓM).ℭsubscriptmodulo𝑎𝑀𝜒¯𝑎𝑟𝑒𝑎¯𝑐𝑛ℓ𝑀\displaystyle\mathfrak{C}=\sum_{a\bmod{M}}\chi(\overline{a}+r)e\left(\frac{a\overline{c}n\ell}{M}\right).

Our job now is to save p​M1/2+θ/N𝑝superscript𝑀12𝜃𝑁pM^{1/2+\theta}/\sqrt{N} in the above sum (beyond square root cancellation in the character sum ℭℭ\mathfrak{C}). Applying Cauchy inequality we seek to save p2​M1+2​θ/Nsuperscript𝑝2superscript𝑀12𝜃𝑁p^{2}M^{1+2\theta}/N in

∑n∼p2​M2/N​L|∑ℓ∈ℒ∑r∼p∑c≪p​M/Ne​(c¯​n​ℓr​M)​χ​(c)¯​ℭ|2.subscriptsimilar-to𝑛superscript𝑝2superscript𝑀2𝑁𝐿superscriptsubscriptℓℒsubscriptsimilar-to𝑟𝑝subscriptmuch-less-than𝑐𝑝𝑀𝑁𝑒¯𝑐𝑛ℓ𝑟𝑀¯𝜒𝑐ℭ2\displaystyle\sum_{n\sim p^{2}M^{2}/NL}\>\Bigl{|}\sum_{\ell\in\mathscr{L}}\>\sum_{r\sim p}\>\sum_{c\ll pM/N}\>e\left(\frac{\overline{c}n\ell}{rM}\right)\overline{\chi(c)}\>\mathfrak{C}\Bigr{|}^{2}.

We will now open the absolute value and apply the Poisson summation formula on the sum over n𝑛n. The diagonal contribution is seen to be satisfactory as long as we have enough terms inside the absolute value, namely p2​L​M/N>p2​M1+2​θ/Nsuperscript𝑝2𝐿𝑀𝑁superscript𝑝2superscript𝑀12𝜃𝑁p^{2}LM/N>p^{2}M^{1+2\theta}/N, i.e. L>M2​θ𝐿superscript𝑀2𝜃L>M^{2\theta}. On the other hand the off-diagonal is satisfactory as long as p2​M2/N​L​M1/2>p2​M1+2​θ/Nsuperscript𝑝2superscript𝑀2𝑁𝐿superscript𝑀12superscript𝑝2superscript𝑀12𝜃𝑁p^{2}M^{2}/NLM^{1/2}>p^{2}M^{1+2\theta}/N, i.e. L<M1/2−2​θ𝐿superscript𝑀122𝜃L<M^{1/2-2\theta}. At this stage we encounter a complete character sum of the form

∑x∈𝔽M−{few points}χ​(P​(x)Q​(x))subscript𝑥subscript𝔽𝑀few points𝜒𝑃𝑥𝑄𝑥\displaystyle\sum_{x\in\mathbb{F}_{M}-\{\text{few points}\}}\>\chi\left(\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}\right)

where P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q are quadratic polynomials. Exactly the same sum appeared in Burgess’ method, and like him we appeal to Weil’s results (Riemann hypothesis for curves over finite fields) to conclude square-root cancellation in the sum. Now we observe that the optimal choice for L𝐿L is given by L=M1/4𝐿superscript𝑀14L=M^{1/4} and θ𝜃\theta is taken to be 1/8181/8. This establishes the bound

1N​|∑n∼Nd​(n)​χ​(n)|≪M1/2−1/8+εmuch-less-than1𝑁subscriptsimilar-to𝑛𝑁𝑑𝑛𝜒𝑛superscript𝑀1218𝜀\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\left|\sum_{n\sim N}d(n)\chi(n)\right|\ll M^{1/2-1/8+\varepsilon}

for all N𝑁N. From this we are able to conclude the Burgess bound

L​(1/2,χ)≪M3/16+ε.much-less-than𝐿12𝜒superscript𝑀316𝜀\displaystyle L(1/2,\chi)\ll M^{3/16+\varepsilon}.

A careful reader will observe that the above sketch works even when the divisor function is replaced by Fourier coefficients for of G​L​(2)𝐺𝐿2GL(2) forms. Below we gives details for this more general case.

3. The set up

Let g𝑔g be a fixed cusp form for S​L​(2,ℤ)𝑆𝐿2ℤSL(2,\mathbb{Z}) with normalized Fourier coefficients λg​(n)subscript𝜆𝑔𝑛\lambda_{g}(n). Let χ𝜒\chi be a primitive Dirichlet character modulo a prime M𝑀M. The approximate functional equation for the twisted L𝐿L-function yields

L​(12,g⊗χ)≪Mε​supN|S​(N)|N1/2+M(1−θ)/2much-less-than𝐿12tensor-product𝑔𝜒superscript𝑀𝜀subscriptsupremum𝑁𝑆𝑁superscript𝑁12superscript𝑀1𝜃2\displaystyle L\left(\tfrac{1}{2},g\otimes\chi\right)\ll M^{\varepsilon}\sup_{N}\frac{|S(N)|}{N^{1/2}}+M^{(1-\theta)/2}

where the supremum is taken over M1−θ<N<M1+εsuperscript𝑀1𝜃𝑁superscript𝑀1𝜀M^{1-\theta}<N<M^{1+\varepsilon}, and S​(N)𝑆𝑁S(N) are sums of the form

S​(N)=∑n=1∞λg​(n)​χ​(n)​W​(nN)𝑆𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝜆𝑔𝑛𝜒𝑛𝑊𝑛𝑁\displaystyle S(N)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\lambda_{g}(n)\chi(n)W\left(\frac{n}{N}\right)

with W𝑊W a smooth bump function supported on [1,2]12[1,2]. We will use the G​L​(2)𝐺𝐿2GL(2) delta method to separate the oscillations of the Fourier coefficients and the character in the above sum.

We start by recalling the G​L​(2)𝐺𝐿2GL(2) delta method. Let p𝑝p be a prime number and let k≡3mod4𝑘modulo34k\equiv 3\bmod{4} be a positive integer (which will be of the size 1/ε1𝜀1/\varepsilon). Let ψ𝜓\psi be a character of 𝔽p×superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}^{\times} satisfying ψ​(−1)=−1=(−1)k𝜓11superscript1𝑘\psi(-1)=-1=(-1)^{k}. We consider ψ𝜓\psi as a character modulo p​M𝑝𝑀pM. The inclusion of M𝑀M, which is the conductor of χ𝜒\chi, in the level is an analogue of the ‘congruence-equation trick’. Let H⋆​(p​M,ψ)superscript𝐻⋆𝑝𝑀𝜓H^{\star}(pM,\psi) be the set of Hecke-normalized newforms and we extend it to Hk​(p​M,ψ)subscript𝐻𝑘𝑝𝑀𝜓H_{k}(pM,\psi) - an orthogonal Hecke basis of the space of cusp forms Sk​(p​M,ψ)subscript𝑆𝑘𝑝𝑀𝜓S_{k}(pM,\psi). Using the Petersson formula we derive

δ​(n,r)=1p−1​∑ψmodp(1−ψ​(−1))​∑f∈Hk​(p​M,ψ)ωf−1​λf​(n)​λf​(r)¯𝛿𝑛𝑟1𝑝1subscriptmodulo𝜓𝑝1𝜓1subscript𝑓subscript𝐻𝑘𝑝𝑀𝜓superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑓1subscript𝜆𝑓𝑛¯subscript𝜆𝑓𝑟\displaystyle\delta(n,r)=\frac{1}{p-1}\;\sum_{\psi\bmod{p}}\left(1-\psi(-1)\right)\sum_{f\in H_{k}(pM,\psi)}\omega_{f}^{-1}\lambda_{f}(n)\overline{\lambda_{f}(r)} (3)

5. Applying functional equations

Next we will apply the functional equation for G​L​(2)×G​L​(2)𝐺𝐿2𝐺𝐿2GL(2)\times GL(2) Rankin-Selberg convolution, and G​L​(2)𝐺𝐿2GL(2) Voronoi summation formula to the sums over (m,n)𝑚𝑛(m,n) and r𝑟r respectively. Applying Mellin inversion formula we get

∑∑m,n=1∞λg​(n)​λf​(n)​ψ​(m)​W​(n​m2N​ℓ)=12​π​i​∫(2)(N​ℓ)s​W~​(s)​L​(s,f⊗g)​ds,superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑛1subscript𝜆𝑔𝑛subscript𝜆𝑓𝑛𝜓𝑚𝑊𝑛superscript𝑚2𝑁ℓ12𝜋𝑖subscript2superscript𝑁ℓ𝑠~𝑊𝑠𝐿𝑠tensor-product𝑓𝑔differential-d𝑠\displaystyle\mathop{\sum\sum}_{m,n=1}^{\infty}\lambda_{g}(n)\lambda_{f}(n)\psi(m)W\left(\frac{nm^{2}}{N\ell}\right)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{(2)}(N\ell)^{s}\tilde{W}(s)L(s,f\otimes g)\mathrm{d}s, (9)

where W~~𝑊\tilde{W} stands for the Mellin transform of W𝑊W. Applying the functional equation (see [12]) we get

12​π​i​∫(2)(N​ℓ)s​W~​(s)​η2​(p​M4​π2)1−2​s​γ​(1−s)γ​(s)​L​(1−s,f⊗g¯)​ds,12𝜋𝑖subscript2superscript𝑁ℓ𝑠~𝑊𝑠superscript𝜂2superscript𝑝𝑀4superscript𝜋212𝑠𝛾1𝑠𝛾𝑠𝐿1𝑠tensor-product𝑓¯𝑔differential-d𝑠\displaystyle\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{(2)}(N\ell)^{s}\tilde{W}(s)\;\eta^{2}\left(\frac{pM}{4\pi^{2}}\right)^{1-2s}\frac{\gamma(1-s)}{\gamma(s)}L(1-s,f\otimes\overline{g})\mathrm{d}s,

where γ​(s)=Γ​(s+(k−κ)/2)​Γ​(s+(k+κ)/2−1)𝛾𝑠Γ𝑠𝑘𝜅2Γ𝑠𝑘𝜅21\gamma(s)=\Gamma(s+(k-\kappa)/2)\Gamma(s+(k+\kappa)/2-1) and κ𝜅\kappa is the weight of the form g𝑔g. The sign of the functional equation

η2=gψ2​ψ2​(M)λg​(M2​p2)​M​p=gψ2​ψ​(M)λg​(p2)​psuperscript𝜂2superscriptsubscript𝑔𝜓2superscript𝜓2𝑀subscript𝜆𝑔superscript𝑀2superscript𝑝2𝑀𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑔𝜓2𝜓𝑀subscript𝜆𝑔superscript𝑝2𝑝\displaystyle\eta^{2}=\frac{g_{\psi}^{2}\psi^{2}(M)}{\lambda_{g}(M^{2}p^{2})Mp}=\frac{g_{\psi}^{2}\psi(M)}{\lambda_{g}(p^{2})p}

where gψsubscript𝑔𝜓g_{\psi} is the Gauss sum associated with the character ψ𝜓\psi. Next we expand the L𝐿L-function into a Dirichlet series and take dyadic subdivision. Since we are taking k𝑘k to be large (like 1/ε1𝜀1/\varepsilon), the poles of the gamma factor are away from 00. We conclude that

ΩΩ\displaystyle\Omega ≪N~​M2​L​p​Cm2+N~​M3/2​L2​p​C2m2+p4​M5/2​C2m4​(1+L2p2),much-less-thanabsent~𝑁superscript𝑀2𝐿𝑝𝐶superscript𝑚2~𝑁superscript𝑀32superscript𝐿2𝑝superscript𝐶2superscript𝑚2superscript𝑝4superscript𝑀52superscript𝐶2superscript𝑚41superscript𝐿2superscript𝑝2\displaystyle\ll\frac{\tilde{N}M^{2}LpC}{m^{2}}+\frac{\tilde{N}M^{3/2}L^{2}pC^{2}}{m^{2}}+\frac{p^{4}M^{5/2}C^{2}}{m^{4}}\>\left(1+\frac{L^{2}}{p^{2}}\right),

from which it follows that

𝒪†≪N2​N~1/2M3​p3​[N~1/2​M3/2​L1/2​pN1/2+N~1/2​M7/4​L​p3/2N+p3​M9/4N​(1+Lp)].much-less-thansuperscript𝒪†superscript𝑁2superscript~𝑁12superscript𝑀3superscript𝑝3delimited-[]superscript~𝑁12superscript𝑀32superscript𝐿12𝑝superscript𝑁12superscript~𝑁12superscript𝑀74𝐿superscript𝑝32𝑁superscript𝑝3superscript𝑀94𝑁1𝐿𝑝\displaystyle\mathscr{O}^{\dagger}\ll\frac{N^{2}\tilde{N}^{1/2}}{M^{3}p^{3}}\;\left[\frac{\tilde{N}^{1/2}M^{3/2}L^{1/2}p}{N^{1/2}}+\frac{\tilde{N}^{1/2}M^{7/4}Lp^{3/2}}{N}+\frac{p^{3}M^{9/4}}{N}\>\left(1+\frac{L}{p}\right)\right].

This reduces to

𝒪†≪N1/2​M1/2L1/2+p1/2​M3/4+N1/2​M1/4L1/2​(p+L).much-less-thansuperscript𝒪†superscript𝑁12superscript𝑀12superscript𝐿12superscript𝑝12superscript𝑀34superscript𝑁12superscript𝑀14superscript𝐿12𝑝𝐿\displaystyle\mathscr{O}^{\dagger}\ll\frac{N^{1/2}M^{1/2}}{L^{1/2}}+p^{1/2}M^{3/4}+\frac{N^{1/2}M^{1/4}}{L^{1/2}}\>\left(p+L\right).

The optimal value L=M1/4𝐿superscript𝑀14L=M^{1/4} is obtained by equating the first and the last term. The optimal value p=Mε​N​L/M=N​M−3/4+ε𝑝superscript𝑀𝜀𝑁𝐿𝑀𝑁superscript𝑀34𝜀p=M^{\varepsilon}NL/M=NM^{-3/4+\varepsilon} is obtained by choosing the minimal possible value for p𝑝p such that the condition required to make the initial off-diagonal negligibly small is satisfied. It follows that 𝒪†≪N1/2​M3/8+εmuch-less-thansuperscript𝒪†superscript𝑁12superscript𝑀38𝜀\mathscr{O}^{\dagger}\ll N^{1/2}M^{3/8+\varepsilon}. The same bound holds for the dual off-diagonal 𝒪⋆superscript𝒪⋆\mathscr{O}^{\star}. Consequently, as min⁡{p,L}≫N​M−3/4−εmuch-greater-than𝑝𝐿𝑁superscript𝑀34𝜀\min\{p,L\}\gg NM^{-3/4-\varepsilon}, we get

S​(N)≪N1/2​M3/8+ε+N3/2​M−9/8+ε+M3/4+ε.much-less-than𝑆𝑁superscript𝑁12superscript𝑀38𝜀superscript𝑁32superscript𝑀98𝜀superscript𝑀34𝜀\displaystyle S(N)\ll N^{1/2}M^{3/8+\varepsilon}+N^{3/2}M^{-9/8+\varepsilon}+M^{3/4+\varepsilon}.

This proves the first theorem, when we take θ=3/4𝜃34\theta=3/4. Now observe that we have not used the cuspidality of g𝑔g. If we replace λg​(n)subscript𝜆𝑔𝑛\lambda_{g}(n) by d​(n)𝑑𝑛d(n), the analysis goes through - only one has to replace the Rankin-Selberg L𝐿L-function at the beginning of Section 5 by L​(s,g)2𝐿superscript𝑠𝑔2L(s,g)^{2}. Thus we get the second theorem.
